title: Duck Stamps Won’t Have to Depict Hunting Imagery
sub_head: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service reverses a Trump-era rule for the annual artwork competition
body:
WASHINGTON—Federal Duck Stamps will no longer be required to show hunting imagery, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said Tuesday as it reversed a Trump administration decree.
Fish and Wildlife oversees an annual competition for the stamp’s artwork, and participation in the contest fell 27% in 2020, the year after the hunting mandate took effect, the agency said.
The change will give “artists more flexibility when designing their art,” Fish and Wildlife said in a statement.
The stamps, which cost $25, must be purchased by waterfowl hunters over the age of 16 but are also widely collected by birders, wildlife photographers and conservationists. Sales support conservation.
The requirement for hunting imagery, such as firearms and decoys, grew out of an initiative by former Trump administration Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke to promote hunting.
